review_title: Bad environment to start your career in
pros: Decent pay Free entry to union events Colleagues of a similar age
cons: The management are very controlling towards the sabbatical officer team, and despite the student body having an image of our role being to enact change, the senior leadership team stopped any meaningful change being made. They would often tear us down privately in their offices under a guise of ‘development’ including telling us we are nasty and making personal comments. Beyond the sabbatical officer team there was a wider culture issue regarding psychological safety, with many colleagues roles being axed unfairly or colleagues feeling scared to provide genuine contributions if they didn’t align with the senior leadership’s own views. In LUU there is a schmoozing game to be played in order to succeed and those not willing to go against their own values to accommodate this will suffer as a result. In the previous year they had even conducted an ‘independent review’ into company issues and it transpired that the independent reviewer was a close external friend of the senior leadership team, so naturally the report showed exactly what they needed it to. This is a very poor first role for a young person having just graduated University (with some even taking it on during their degree) as the self-esteem issues and mental pain that remembering my time here has caused would not be worth it for anything.

pros: Excellent flexibility. The job itself is fun, the workplace however....
cons: Overly corporate. Managers that have never been in lower roles and don't understand the day to day running of the ground level of the business. Pay is much less than the average for similar roles in Leeds despite high profits AND being tax exempt due to being a registered charity. Stupid rules that make no sense. Unclear and vague rules and policies. Higher up managers socialise in the workplace which makes staff uncomfortable. Severe lack of training given to new starters to the point of potentially putting people in danger. Ridiculously high staff turn over yet cares more about "diverse hiring" than hiring competent staff.

review_title: Great springboard for future moves, but no career progression there
pros:
Great job to have on the side of studies, and for new graduates it's certainly a great springboard for other opportunities. 

Not working holidays and flexibility around Christmas is a massive bonus.
cons:
The organisation suffers at the behest of its poor management – 'Led by Donkeys' springs to mind. Frequently have been told not to 'upset' or 'rock the boat' with director-level staff. Career progression is difficult, it's normal for those in management positions to stay 10+ years. It can also suffer from the flexibility it is proud to offer. Management make moves to go increasingly part-time and the turnover of junior or lower-level staff is therefore frequent since you're overworked and there's nowhere to go.

Student staff are also currently excluded from Pay & Reward (bonus) schemes. The current scheme involves individuals making applications, which are judged by senior management.

pros:
- the union is a great place to work as a student as you don't have to stay during holidays 
- the managers are really understanding about time off and university commitments
- it's super easy to swap your shifts 
- depending on how much effort you put in with your colleagues you can make some good friends
cons: - the pay isnt the same for all ages, and it's a bit of a kick in the teeth to have to work for 5 quid when everyone over 21 is doing the same job as you but getting 6.50 or whatever the minimum wage is now

pros: The work environment at our office was absolutely astounding. Everyone had a great work ethic, was positive at all times and very supportive. My training has been extensive and continues to this day.
cons: I believe many of the staff and especially those in the office I worked at were probably underpaid on the basis of how much they actually do and contribute. I think the cons stop there.

review_title: An engaging atmosphere but no scope for progression and overworked staff.
pros: LUU has some real positives as a workplace. It’s always interesting and varied, you learn a huge range of different   skills and you will meet some of the most genuinely lovely people imaginable. They have great holidays, online training courses, and campus is a delightful place to work where you can see real change being implemented. It’s also a great place to work part time as a student.
cons:
However, unfortunately all of these pluses are more than cancelled out by the negatives that working at LUU offers on the flip side. The pay is incredibly poor, the place runs on underpaid graduates who work way above their pay grade for a couple of years before leaving and realising they’re worth more, at which point LUU hires a carbon copy graduate and the cycle repeats. 
There is a huge divide between commercial and non commercial departments. Commercial departments slog to make money to keep the union literally with a hot water supply, while non-commercial departments spend the money on unnecessary events and pointless campaigns. This is done all in the name of creating a better space and experience for students, without realising that without the commercial teams there would be no money to keep the building and staff, never mind put on campaigns in the name of inclusivity. The majority of senior management are clueless, condescending, and make huge errors in their work without any comeuppance. Meanwhile, the people at ‘assistant’ and ‘coordinator’ level are bearing the brunt of their poorly judged actions. If you want a career job where you are appreciated, with the possibility of progression and monetary reward for your hard work, this isn’t the place for you. If you want a couple of years of experience in a rich, diverse and challenging environment with no long term plans to stay, and you have savings or money from another income, it will be perfect for you.
